Dear Loren:
I am delighted to learn that your upset was not serious. You may have
got your tnsldes twisted, but you always have your head on straight!
Consequently I was rather dismayed when I arrived and found that you
would not be available for the Board meeting. I counted on you heavily
to lay the groundwork for the discussion of the NAEB-NETRC relationship.
However, I survived this handicap and It conditioned me a bit for the
second blow. On the eve of the House hearings. Bob Schenkan had,
what was first reported to be, a heart attack. Since he was scheduled
to arrive In Washington to steer the political activity during these three
days, this was a highly unfortunate circumstance. Bob's trouble turned
out to be less grave than at first diagnosed. Evidently he had just overÂ¬
worked to the point of exaustion and collapsed.
Anyway, She board meeting went off rather well. We cleared the air
with reference to the Channel 12 situation and reestablished friendly
relations with the Philadelphia branch. Nothtng conclusive came from
the discussion over the MAEB-NETRC letter of agreement. X do believe,
however, that we have laid the groundwork for a fruitful outcome at
Columbus.
Somehow, In the midst of the hearings, I will manage to dictate an account
of the meeting to distribute to the Board so that you will have more details.
Cordially yours.
WGHjrkf
William G. Harley
President
